body: To be a little more specific, if I save a change on a static resource (i.e, foobar.html) on my dev machine, I can see that the update syncs all the way to the docker container. However, when I refresh the page, the server sends the old static resource with a 200 response. So it appears that static resources changes are not detected, and the static resources in the running application are therefore not refreshed. When I do this on my dev machine (not a shared folder), the static file is updated w.r.t the running application without a recompile.
When the sync is done, is the modification time of the file being updated too?

I think so, but not as I'd expect. This is before making a change to main.html:

```
[vagrant@vagrant assessments]$ ls -l
total 12
-rw-r--r--. 1 503 games 1881 Apr  8 18:36 controllers.js
-rw-r--r--. 1 503 games 3147 Apr  9 12:39 main.html
-rw-r--r--. 1 503 games  232 Apr  7 18:10 main.js
```

This is after making a change:

```
[vagrant@vagrant assessments]$ ls -l
total 12
-rw-r--r--. 1 503 games 1881 Apr  8 18:36 controllers.js
-rw-r--r--. 1 503 games 3147 Apr  9  2015 main.html
-rw-r--r--. 1 503 games  232 Apr  7 18:10 main.js
```

Is there a better way to check this?

We could be on to something here.  Try using the `stat` command instead, on Linux:

```
$ stat -t main main.html
```

This should show the raw timestamp values.  I'm not sure, but it looks like the timestamp on `main.html` is losing precision after an update, to one day, which means the sbt change detection algorithm, which is based on the timestamp being more recent then when it was last checked, would not work.

The timestamp was being updated, usually with a significant lag (~10 seconds), whereas the file contents were updated immediately. So now I've made a change my Vagrantfile from this:

```
config.vm.synced_folder ".", "/vagrant", type: "nfs", nfs_export: false, nfs_udp: false
```

to this:

```
config.vm.synced_folder ".", "/vagrant", type: "nfs", nfs_export: false, nfs_udp: false, mount_options: ["lookupcache=none"]
```

Now the timestamp is updated immediately (and without the weird `ls -l` formatting quirk).

Before modifying `main.html`:

```
[root@883b8c551a75 assessments]# stat main.html
  File: `main.html'
  Size: 3147        Blocks: 8          IO Block: 65536  regular file
Device: 28h/40d Inode: 3294893     Links: 1
Access: (0644/-rw-r--r--)  Uid: (  503/ UNKNOWN)   Gid: (   20/   games)
Access: 2015-04-10 15:25:31.000000000 +0000
Modify: 2015-04-10 15:29:25.000000000 +0000
Change: 2015-04-10 15:29:25.000000000 +0000
```

After modifying `main.html`:

```
[root@883b8c551a75 assessments]# stat main.html
  File: `main.html'
  Size: 3148        Blocks: 8          IO Block: 65536  regular file
Device: 28h/40d Inode: 3294893     Links: 1
Access: (0644/-rw-r--r--)  Uid: (  503/ UNKNOWN)   Gid: (   20/   games)
Access: 2015-04-10 15:25:31.000000000 +0000
Modify: 2015-04-10 15:29:41.000000000 +0000
Change: 2015-04-10 15:29:41.000000000 +0000
```

You can see that the seconds changed from 25 to 41 as expected. This looks like progress.

Unfortunately though, refreshing the page in the browser still doesn't trigger an update to the static content in the running application (the server returns the unchanged file). This line is in my `build.sbt`:

```
PlayKeys.playWatchService := play.sbtplugin.run.PlayWatchService.sbt(pollInterval.value)
```

Ok, can you add the following to your build:

``` scala
play.Play.playReload := {
  println("Reload triggered")
  play.Play.playReload.value
}
```

Then make the change, and refresh the browser, and if it doesn't work immediately, refresh a few more times, and let me know whether `Reload triggered` is printed out to the sbt console.

Oh, I've seen that too. (But haven't bothered to look at the issue closely until now.) The `.distinct` call [here](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/ecc1a1f175eb85b6d89ac893d75973c612cca942/framework/src/run-support/src/main/scala/play/runsupport/FileWatchService.scala#L119) operates only on file names, not full paths, which means something like `views/a/main.html, views/b/main.html, views/c/main.html, views/other.html` becomes `views/a/main.html, views/other.html`.

The `Reload triggered` message did not print to the sbt console when I modified a static resource, even after several page refreshes. It did print when I made a change to `app/controllers/Application.scala` and then refreshed the page a few times.

In light of @shkhln's comment, I tried modifying a static resource that has a unique filename. Unfortunately, this didn't trigger a reload either.
@shkhln your MySbtWatchService appears to have resolved the issue. I now get the `Reload triggered` message, and the server returns the modified asset.

@shkhln I just confirmed that it works for both Vagrant boxes I'm using (one with devicemapper, the other with BTRFS). There is some lag, but I suppose that's due to the pollingInterval and the time it takes to complete the file scan. This is a major improvement.

So the only different between that and the built in Play one is the lack of a `distinct` call?  That's odd, because `distinct` uses `Object.equals` equality, and for `File`, that _should_ be based on the full path.  What happens if you change the `println` statement to:

``` scala
println("filesToWatch:\n" + filesToWatch.***.distinct)
```

Are there any files missing?

Sorry, I always forget to mention something important. It is the (poorly named) [sbt.PathFinder.distinct](https://github.com/sbt/sbt/blob/127081b3c5af07058a88f0130e0cfd7fe0838e7a/util/io/src/main/scala/sbt/Path.scala#L176) method, not stdlib one.

issue.title: PathFinder.distinct is based on file name, not path
issue.body:
If I have the following files:
- `a/b/foo.txt`
- `a/c/foo.txt`

And I do:

``` scala
file("a").***.distinct
```

I end up with only one file, even though there are two distinct paths, because the implementation of `distinct` matches on file name, not file path.

See https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/4208 for an example of issues this can cause.

issue.title: Two files with same name are both watched

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Fixes #4208

If two files had the same name (in different directories), the sbt watcher only watched one of them.  This fixes that.
